Many doctors who have written books on the subject recommend diets high in fat and extremely low in carbohydrates, limiting them at 10% of caloric intake.  It is unclear how pragmatically one could live on just 10% carbohydrate.  The latter represents the most efficient source of energy for the body.  Athletic performance, endurance would suffer with only 10% carbohydrate.    I gather the idea of the high fat diet is to change the metabolic state of the body in a state of ketosis whereby given the absence of readily available carbohydrate fuel, the body learns how to use and burn fat for energy.  Is this process all that healthy and sustainable over the long term?  And, would it enhance cognitive capabilities over the long term as one ages. -

question_title: Is there a service that translates medical reports into everyday language?
question_body: Medical reports can be quite long and may contain complicated vocabulary that is difficult or impossible for patients to understand. In Germany, theres a website called   (What do I have?) to which a patient may submit their medical report. Students of medicine (8th term upwards) and MDs who participate in the project translate said report into everyday language. They explain the concepts behind symptoms and prescriptions in a way that is easy to understand. This is a lot of work: I have seen people work twenty hours on a single, complicated letter, and a medical report of two pages may very well translate into a document of twenty pages. This work is done in their spare time and is not paid. This service is offered to patients free of charge because it should be absolutely independent of a patients income. The platform is funded through donations. Is there an English service where patients can get their medical reports explained / translated into everyday language? If so, is it gratuitous?-j9657d3sas8ej3a

question_title: Do periodontal exams spread infection?
question_body: When a dentist is measuring how far gums have receded and looking for infection below the gum line they use a probe which they insert below the gum line and record how far it goes before hitting healthy tissue (or at least that is my understanding). They record the depth measurement of a tooth and then move onto the next using the same probe and without washing it in between.  It seems to me that this would be a great way to spread infection from one gum to the next. I asked my hygienist why this isn't considered unsafe. She started to explain to me why it wasn't dangerous and then caught herself and said "I don't know". So am I right to be concerned? Might they be unwittingly spreading infection throughout the mouth by this seemingly unsanitary exam practice?-

She only said the wound has healed too much, and now it cant heal anymore without knocking it back first. I asked for more details and got a similar response back.  Can anyone give me some clarification as to the biological process going on and what the nitrate treatment is supposed to accomplish?  Thanks  -tq041elcu8oe7a

question_title: Why is thalidomide a current drug on the market?

question_title: Ice bath cryolipolysis?

This makes me wonder, couldn't one just spend time in an icebath? Various sources spread throughout the internet, most notably plastic surgeons, answer this with the trivial, "No! The CoolSculpting device is special and safe, and any method of cryolipolysis not using the device would be dangerous!" but from a medical perspective, why not? This is the point where I explicitly say ice baths can cause hypothermia and a host of other issues, so I'm definitely not recommending it personally, but medically, wouldn't time with the torso in an ice bath, with a wetsuit/drysuit covering the legs and groin, have the same effect as CoolSculpting, but for thousands of times lower cost?-

question_title: References for comprehensive guideline for individualized vaccination schedules
question_body: For the most developed countries there exists   which result from an in depth analysis of the risk-benefit ratio for the general population. I.e. it is (or should be) the best available schedule  . Lots of physicians follow strictly those guidelines. However considering a particular individual, you can take other variables into account, which may result in a different optimal vaccination schedule. The only information usually taken into account are diseases which result in a clear contraindication for a particular vaccination. However there are more variables with less impact on the schedule but which may relevant to (slightly) optimize the benefit-risk ratio for the individual.  For example if you have a newborn from a familiy with contact to the drug scene should clearly have a hepatitis B vaccination. However in other families there is clearly (almost) no risk that the infant comes into contact with someone having hepatitis B (for example because of the families social environment and because the infant doesn't go to a nursery), the risks of unintended side effects might be larger then the benefits. Then the doctor should explain this to the parents and also point out that the social environment and thus the risk may change if the child is at puberty and that it might be difficult to send the child to vaccination at this age... Another example would be the FSME vaccination. If a infant lives in a big city you might come to a different recommendation than for a child of a farmer family living in a FSME risky environment.  A further example is the rota virus. In this case the recommendation might be different if the mother is breastfeeding or not.  Also the timing may depend, for example if a infant is raised at home for the first three years, you might consider giving the vaccination a a bit later than for a infant which is in a nursery the whole day since month 2. So are there any books or papers which discusses those aspects of individualized optimizing the vaccination schedule in a comprehensive way supported by reliable probabilities and reasoning. Because of different available vaccines and different risks of getting infected, the answer depends on the country. In particular I am interested in Germany. But discussions based on the situation in other European countries or the US may be comparable. Where as the situation in some African countries will be very different (that's not what I want). Furthermore my interest is mainly focused on the typical vaccinations during childhood and not about travel vaccinations.-

question_title: Is there any known link between cholecystitis (gall bladder inflammation) and breastfeeding?
question_body: I have helped new mothers with breastfeeding for over a decade now.  I am often surprised how many end up with their gall bladder removed within the year following birth, many in the first few months.  Many will say they had some irritation during pregnancy, while many also had no indications at all.  I am well educated on the mechanics of breastfeeding and it's biological components within the mother.  It is well known that while breastfeeding, you release a linear peptide called CCk (cholecystekinin) that aids in digestion, and it floods your systems and is excreted in the milk.  Among the actions CCK is triggering, a major one is the gall bladder to release bile.   In most cases I am seeing, the woman is under 30, in otherwise relatively good health, no history of being overweight, etc.  I cannot seem to understand why so frequently I am seeing such young women with no major risk factors have this issue and am trying to understand it it's preventable.  I became interested when it happened to  .  I had a doctor willing to help me look at life changes to support my gall bladder through diet to see if it could heal.  I cannot say I will never need it out, I am at higher risk that I will, eventually.  My current enzymes have been stable and fine for years and that I kept my gall bladder and had another baby without any flares.  I had to follow a pretty strict diet for a year and then I was able to slowly add foods back in and my inflammation seemed to subside.  I went back to a stricter diet after birth, due to my prior experience, but that was merely a precaution.  I do not think that is possible in all cases, this was only after thorough exams and talks with my doctor that he felt it   be worth trying to heal it versus removal. My thought is if we could know what puts a specific mother at risk, perhaps we could preemptively help her take measures to avoid the issue.  It's considered a minor surgery generally, but no mother wants surgery when recovering from birth and trying to take care of a young baby, etc.  I would love if I could find any link there as I have poked around trying to understand a potential link for at least 8 years now since I went through it.  I have no anecdotal statistics on this, but I can tell you that in helping about 50 mothers a month, I am getting 4-5 in there asking me about the effects of this surgery on breastfeeding, every month.  That seems very high to me for healthy women in this age range.-

question_title: Is our use of cooking oils responsible for the insufficient conversion of Omega-3 to EPA and DHA?
question_body: It is well known that the conversion rate of Omega-3 to EPA and DHA is too low to supply us with the required amounts. But this is nevertheless a strange situation, why would natural selection have led to a vulnerability where lack of seafood means that you're going to be deficient on EPA and DHA? But if we dig deeper and consider someone who only eats natural foods, then we need to consider that such a person will not eat any refined fats and oils. Such a person would end up getting all the fats from vegetables, nuts and seeds, the fats contained in there are for a large part Omega-3 and Omega-6 fats. This doesn't seem to be relevant to the low conversion rate, however, when sticking to such a diet on the long term, a large fraction of the body fat would become the Omega-3 and Omega-6 fats that this person eats. Then given that in a natural setting, the Omega-3 in the human body is present in high concentrations in fat tissue, it seems to me that it's there that the enzymes that convert Omega-3 to EPA and DHA should be present. The low conversion rate in our bodies is then due to having filled the fat cells with saturated fats an mono-unsaturated fats with only very small amounts of poly-unsaturated fats.-

question_title: Has the calorie content of soda (in US) increased over the years?
question_body: I recall reading, perhaps 25 years ago, one of those counter-intuitive factoids noting that milk had more calories than soda, ounce for ounce (but of course that this was offset by nutritional benefits of milk). I believe this was referring to skim milk, widely quoted (and presumably stable over time) at 90 calories per 8 ounces, or 135 calories per 12 ounces. And I think I remember noticing that it made sense because a 12-ounce can of (regular sweetened) soda was typically labeled as less than this -- the number I picture seeing is 120 calories. But in recent times I see 12-ounce cans of soda labeled as at least 140 and sometimes 150+ calories, reversing the comparison that I thought used to be made. I am unable to find mention of lower calorie contents in the past or evidence of the factoid I recall (skim milk > soda). I know it is a bit ill-defined because of variation between brands/types of soda. So: was a typical 12-ounce regular soda (Coke, Pepsi, etc.) 140-150 calories even 25 years ago? Has it increased (which I can imagine might happen gradually over time due to a stealth "sweetness war")? Or is my recollection off (perhaps the original comparison was to   milk and so I'm thinking of the wrong numbers)?-

question_title: For varicella zoster(chickenpox), when are vaccination / antiviral drugs effective?
question_body: The UK does not routinely vaccinate its citizens against chickenpox though the info website of the chief healthcare provider acknowledges that vaccinations are available and there are also circumstances where antiviral drugs may be prescribed I recently received advice from my doctor that there isn't much point in either vaccinating or prescribing drugs for chickenpox, and the consensus for adults who have never had chickenpox seems to basically be that you take your chances, suffer the infection should it be contracted and serious complications are unlikely though it's more unpleasant to contract as an adult than as a child I'm thus confused as to why the NHS website would create one impression (steps can be taken for adults with no chickenpox immunity) and the doctor another slightly different impression (steps aren't taken..). While there isn't a direct contradiction, neither source has said when steps are taken, but the doctor implied that steps aren't taken because there is no point. In what context would it make sense for an adult with no immunity to get vaccinated, or to take antiviral drugs? I presume that vaccination would only be successful up to the point that said adult is exposed - walk into a party and be greeted by a child with full on chickenpox and it's too late for vaccination.. but what about antivirals? Could that adult go home, and start a course of drugs that would effectively kill any viruses they'd contracted, before developing a full blown infection of their own? What about the situation where said adult lives with a child who wakes up one morning with a chickenpox rash? Given that the child is apparently contagious a few days before the first spot, is the adult likely too far along the infection timeline themselves for antivirals to have any effect? Is there a point of no return, beyond which AV drugs are ineffective, and for chickenpox this point is  so early that it's usually too late by the time anyone realises?-

question_title: On the mechanics of chickenpox immunity for newborns and breastmilk antibody transfer
question_body: According to my healthcare provider, a newborn should not be affected by chicken pox if it has immunity thanks to his mother having had the infection as a child herself - this immunity is apparently womb gained and lasts roughly a year. Let's assume that the infant is also breastfed exclusively - apparently, this assists the immunity because the mother's milk contains antibodies the newborn can use for resistance to various infections. It seems like there is thus a mechanism where antibodies can be acquired from the mother and used by an infant to fight a disease. I'm told that breastfed babies do not get sick as often as formula fed ones, because disease the mother is exposed to causes antibodies to pass from the mother to the baby in the breast milk. -

question_title: Alternate appendicitis treatment: Appendix drain via colonoscopy
question_body: I know that appendicitis can be successfully treated with antibiotics and that 1 reason healthcare cost is so high in the US compared to other countries is appendectomies for almost all cases of appendicitis. But the bacteria that get trapped in the appendix in someone with appendicitis are gut flora that help our immune system not overreact and make vitamins such as vitamin K. And research shows that the appendix is a safe house for gut flora when someone has a lot of vomiting and diarrhea that would wash away the gut flora. So people who have appendectomies done have to take probiotics after an illness with vomiting and diarrhea to help replenish the gut flora. Taking antibiotics kills most of the good bacteria which is good for appendicitis but not good in the long term. Some antibiotic resistant bacteria such as C. diff which is normally found in the microbiome can cause colitis after taking antibiotics and this colitis can be deadly. So I thought of an alternative to appendectomies and antibiotics for people with appendicitis. Colonoscopy, specifically drainage of the appendix. This would allow the mucus and gut flora to flow from the inflamed appendix to the colon and stop the appendicitis from getting any worse. In other words, it would prevent the appendix from rupturing. And if there are a few living cells of the appendix left after an appendectomy, it can regenerate itself. Of course this would mean a higher percentage of people having reoccurring appendicitis but it could also mean a longer appendix in people who have previously had appendicitis. And a longer appendix would be able to keep even more gut flora safe from being washed away due to vomiting and diarrhea. But is this a reasonable alternative to have people with appendicitis go for a colonoscopy to drain their appendix?-

question_title: Hospital says their blood test caused sepsis. How serious is this?
question_body: My wife went to an Ontario (Canada) public hospital and they performed a blood test, among other things. The test revealed a presence of bacteria in the blood. They said they will send it for analysis to determine the exact bacteria, which may take up to 48 hours.  Somebody from the hospital called a day or so later and said that there's no need to worry, the bacteria should be all gone, and it was most likely introduced into the blood stream (and the sample) during the actual blood test. They said there's no need for follow-up tests. They mentioned that the needle was sterile, but the bacteria was probably on her skin. Is this normal? I thought that with proper procedures your risk of infection should be essentially zero. How effective is the sterilizing wipe that is used before inserting the needle? I'm asking whether what happened (ie blood contaminated during a blood test) is a fairly normal occurrence or if it indicates non-trivial issues with the hospital staff's procedures that should be brought to someone's attention. In other words, something like "Yeah, this happens sometimes, it's not a big deal" vs "Uh.. you should really notify your local health authority ASAP, there's a clear health hazard for other patients".-

question_title: Whatever happened to Tonsillitis?
question_body: 70 or so years ago, kids all got their tonsils out. I have a family member who, when perfectly healthy, had them out (75 or more years ago) because his twin was having his out, and it would be too hard on his mother to have only one twin in the hospital, and she would likely have to go through that again eventually, so get it over with. I have another who had them out about 55 years ago because "I got sick all the time." Yet nobody under 40 (who I know, in North America) has stories like these about themselves or their children. Infants these days get ear infections, which generally clear up before school age one way or another. Some get tubes. But these tales of 4-10 year olds getting their tonsils out and getting to eat ice cream (in various picture books I own) just don't seem to match present-day reality. Why? Do tonsils not get infected any more? Have doctors decided removing them is a bad strategy? -

question_title: How can a TMJ disorder limit one's physical output?
question_body: I recently saw a jaw specialist who did a series of tests to determine if there was a problem in my jaw. The clinic specializes in providing treatment to people with a TMJ (temporomandibular joint) disorder. I am particularly curious about one of the tests he performed. The test went as follows: The result was that, after holding the tongue depressors in my mouth, I was able to resist much harder than before (the doctor was unable to push my arms down). My physical capacity increased significantly.  The doctor explained to me that the tongue depressors created a gap in my mouth that allowed my TMJ to decompress. He said that, when my jaw was in its normal position, the brain was in a state of trying to protect itself and so my physical output was being limited. He mentioned the term, "fight or flight". According to him, after the tongue depressors put a gap between my teeth, the brain was no longer being signaled to protect itself and so my physical output was not being limited.  I've had cuts and scrapes before and I don't believe they have impacted my physical performance, but with the test he conducted, there was a significant difference.  How does this test actually work and why is my physical output being limited by a problem with my jaw?  Reference: 1. Management of Temporomandibular Joint Dysfunction. Published by Jemima Atkins. question_title: Anatomy of Knee Locking That Heals in Weeks [closed]
question_body: I am trying to understand the anatomy of my injury.  I was cutting to the left in basketball. My right knee popped 3 times and I felt sharp pain. Immediately after the injury I couldn't extend my leg any more.  I can extend it to about 20-30 deg from straight. After that I get a sharp pain in anterior-medial below the patella (where the meniscus is).   After the injury I could flex it almost all the way. Two days after it locks 45 degrees from fully bent. At that point I get a sharp pain in posterior-lateral region of the knee (in the knee crevice).  I can put moderete weight on my leg, but can't walk without crutches because I cannot straighten it.   I had the exact same injury (simptoms) 2 times in my life before. Each time, I would stay in bed 2-3 weeks and could limp. A month or two and I could walk/run. I also had an ACL surgery 8 months ago (after those two times).  I can't understand why my knee locks. The general belief is that a part of meniscus is stuck underneath the knee and this is in line with my immediate locking. However, I feel like it doesn't explain why I am able to region the range of motion 2-3 weeks after the injury. Is there any other explanation?-

question_title: Chronic sleep problem - blue-light glasses stopped working
question_body: I have had chronic sleep problems for 11 years. It started very suddenly. I ended up taking zimovane for about 3 and 1/2 years, almost every day. I had to kick that habit as after a while I needed to increase dosage for it to be effective.  Each night followed a similar pattern: I'd have no problem falling asleep but it would be a very shallow sleep and during the night I'd wake up fully. Some nights I'd fall back into a shallow sleep, others I'd be awake until morning. I basically tried everything and nothing worked.  However last October I started to wear blue-light blocking glasses 3 hours before bed and the results were miraculous: I suddenly started to sleep 7 hours straight. I could not believe it. The glasses block blue-light entering the pineal gland. Blue light hitting the pineal gland suppresses the production of melatonin.  The glasses kept working until last April I noticed I started to sleep less deeply again. Each night got a little bit worse and in the last 2 weeks I've barely had 2 or 3 hours sleep per night. I've had to quit my job as a result.  Im baffled and deeply sad that the blue-light blocking glasses are no longer proving effective. I have some theories: 1/ some studies show melatonin production naturally decreases in summer. However taking melatonin tablets does not help me at all. I also each foods rich in melatonin such as cherries and bananas, and take magnesium, vitamin B6 & B5, but to no avail. I  2/ light is a form of radiation - perhaps other forms of radiation such as electromagnetic radiation from devices are keep me awake? This would be depressing as I work in IT and I live in an apartment block where everyone has Wifi (and I'm therefor being constantly hit with Wifi signals). Im not sure if this is proven science though. These are just 2 of my theories. Is there any reason why I would suddenly begin to sleep badly again? Could it be seasonal? It's not something I can deal with - I had to quit a 2 year job I liked very much as I simply could not work effectively on 3/4 hours disrupted sleep. I'm getting very desperate. Please advise.   I wonder would a EMF canopy help me? -

question_title: Health Benefit of Social Nudity - Improvement of Homeostasis?
question_body: I have been conducting extensive research over the last few years on the history of nudity in social situations, and I am looking to expand my research base now I have come across a few other interesting facts. Additionally to another question I asked, I am asking... Professor Peter Wheeler of Liverpool John Moores University says that the average human can lose heat at a rate in excess of 1 kilowatt, which is the amount of heat put out by a 1 bar electric fire.  If you have body hair, you can still lose heat by sweating, but the rate of heat loss will be reduced because the air flow across the body would be severely reduced which in turn would reduce the rate at which the sweat is going to evaporate.  Sweating into a fur coat would have been no use to our ancestors. ( ) ( ) Horizon: What's The Problem With Nudity (2008). [TV] Directed by Paul King. UK:BBC.  BBC iPlayer:  Wheeler, P. E. (1994).  . Journal of Human Evolution 21(2): pp. 107-115. DOI:  Does this indicate one physical benefit to nudity (quicker heat loss for body temperature regulation).-76951e

question_title: Health Benefit of Social Nudity - Parasite Reduction?
question_body: I have been conducting extensive research over the last few years on the history of nudity in social situations, and I am looking to expand my research base now I have come across a few other interesting facts. Additionally to  , I am asking... Dr. David Reed of Florida University has been studying human lice and found that wearing clothes introduced a new form of human lice (the clothing lice). (Image  Head louse on the left, clothing louse on the right - Source:  ) Would going nude reduce Clothing Lice? Clothing Lice is a direct descendant of the head louse.  The genetic data for this branch of lice would give us a date when humans started to get dressed and the data indicates that our ancestral humans lived naked for at least 2 million years.  Clothing was first used at least 83,000 years ago and possibly as early as 170,000 years ago ( ) ( ).  If you take the median of these dates that makes it approximately 127,000 years ago. Horizon: What's The Problem With Nudity (2008). [TV] Directed by Paul King. UK:BBC.  BBC iPlayer:  Reed, D. L., et al. (2011).  . Molecular Biology and Evolution 28(1): pp. 29-32. DOI: -l60d590406a

question_title: When is it most effective to take a Tryptophan supplement?
question_body: Tryptophan is an amino acid and a building block for certain hormones such as melatonin and serotonin. If you're looking to improve your mood I would imagine taking a Tryptophan supplement may be most effective in the morning to enhance serotonin production whereas if you're trying to address issues with sleep you may opt to take a Tryptophan supplement in the early evening to enhance melatonin production. When is it most effective to take a Tryptophan supplement for subjective to mood or sleep related issues?-

question_title: Should I still worry about my Omega-3 to Omega 6 ratio when I consume other anti-inflammatory foods with my meals?
question_body: I hear that we must maintain a healthy ratio of Omega-3 to Omega-6 fats of at most 1:4 to avoid excessive inflammation in the body. However, Omega-3 fats are so hard to find in significant quantities in regular foods, and the few Omega-3 rich foods that do exist are pretty pricey. So, I was thinking. Does the ratio still really matter that much when you're consuming other kinds of anti-inflammatory foods like cinnamon with your meals? Wouldn't cinnamon, for example, serve the same purpose as Omega-3 fats as far as anti-inflammation goes that would allow me not to worry too much about the ratio of Omega-3 to Omega-6 fats?-

question_title: Can carbonated water produce addiction in humans?
question_body: Recently I have been quite heavily drinking beer, and noticed a strange effect: apparently an addiction developed but not to alcohol but to CO2.  Basically, now I cannot satisfy my thristyness with non-carbonated drinks, such as tap water, tea and milk. Today I felt thristyness all the day despite drinking a lot of milk products and tap water. All the day I was drinking and pissing, but still was thristy. Finally, after 4th glass of tap water in a row, without any hope to combat my thristyness I went to a store and took a bottle of carbonated mineral water.  Instantly when I started drinking it my eyes filled with tears of satisfaction and the thristyness went away. So, I suspect I developed some kind of dependence on CO2 dissolved in water.-

question_title: move across the country now i get sick [closed]
question_body: Ok so this is pretty bizarre hopefully someone could lead me in the right direction.so I lived in Los Angeles all my life and moved to north Carolina last year once I got settled in I went out to a gastro pub.i got a burger and about 30 minutes later got the worst stomach pain in my life it literally felt like a knife was inside moving around I could barely focus on driving back home and was sweating a good amount.iam not trying to sound macho or anything but I tend to have a high tolerance for pain when I was a little kid I once went swimming with a broken arm all day it hurt yes but I wanted to swim more. So now I get home and do my thing on the toilet,then feel somewhat better still stayed up all night with stomach aches.finally the next day I feel back to normal and thought maybe I was allergic to something in the food.i dont think you could get food poisoning that fast?so here comes the whole kicker of the story.I decided to go make my own burgers and I get sick with the same symptoms they varied a little but ultimately the same.I tried every stores brand grass fed,non gmo,and regular processed meat still the same.weird thing is i can eat beef at any restaurant,haven't been back to the gastro pub though. to add even more confusion when i went back to LA i can eat any store bought meat no problem.any help is appreciated iam just at a lost for what could cause it,i even tried buying meat and cook it right away when i got home thinking my refrigerator might be broken nope still the same.let me know what you think or should try.thanks-

question_title: Decision to not wear contact lenses any longer and instead set my computer to 110 - 125% zoom,
question_body: I feel that my eyesight is deteriorating faster when wearing contact lenses all day long, so lately I've been doing work without them and actually have just minimal issues with reading on the computer screen - sometimes I'll have to zoom to 110 to 125% to read a paper, though.  In fact, my eyes actually feel 'healthier' from not having dried up lenses in my eyes, which, at the end of the work day, makes my eyes itch and turn really red.  Without wearing lenses recently, I also feel more 'awake' and lively, without experiencing dry eyes by late afternoon. Is zooming in on the computer screen (when needed) a 'healthier' option to go with, instead of wearing contacts all day long? FWIW, I don't drive a car.  When walking on the streets at night, I do notice that my visibility is not great, so perhaps I'll wear lenses only when needing to travel between places.  So, my question really is specific to doing work at a desk - on a computer, reading a book, a paper, etc.  Is it ok to go without lenses?   (Naturally, I do not want to ask this question to my optometrist, because I feel he's in the business of selling me contact lenses, eye exams, and glasses.  There's little chance he would give me a complete story, I think, so hence I am asking the question here instead.) Thanks,-

However the labels on some of these shampoos do not provide any indication on how long the shampoo would need to stay on the scalp before rinsing it off. Are there any guidelines how long this kind of shampoo should be left on the scalp before rinsing it off?-

question_title: Can a healthy baby / new born be carried longer when the weather is hot if carried skin to skin against its father's chest?
question_body: One day I asked a General Practitioner if a father could go outside with his baby / new born while the weather was hot (let's say around 30-35C), carrying it skin to skin against the father's chest in a carrying scarf. The GP's answer was "obviously the father shouldn't". Unfortunately the GP could not explain me why the father should not. So I wanted to know if in a carrying scarf (skin to skin against the father's chest) the adult's body could help the baby's one to regulate its temperature, throwing away the exceeding heating from the baby. Or put another way can the adult's body act as a heat exchanger to keep the baby's internal temperature around the adult's body temperature (~ 37C) ? Or would it be worse and would the baby's internal temperature increases up to risky values ? Thanks in advance to whoever that can shed me some lights!-yv7a2z

question_title: Does eating too much cocoa have harmful side effects?
question_body: My question concerns the consumption of pure, unsweetened cocoa. The cocoa to be consumed could either be boiled or mixed with tap water. Its consistency could range from buttery to creamy to soda-like. I could consume the cocoa without any sweeteners or other additives, although occasionally I might add a dash of cinnamon or other spice or even a teaspoon of peanut to sweeten it up a bit. Leaving aside the dietary limits for these occasional additives, is there a practical limit to the amount of cocoa a healthy person could consume per day? I understand that eating a kilo of anything, even so-called "super foods", could make you sick, but as a practical diet plan, I'm thinking of a regimen that consists of oatmeal with cocoa for breakfast, a lunch of cocoa-coated veggie fries, chilled cocoa with peanut butter or whipped cream for my dinner dessert, and the usual sauces and dips made out of cocoa. In short, every meal will have the dark brown powder as an ingredient. This isn't an entirely hypothetical question. I've adopted a cocoa-based diet as a means of curbing my unhealthy craving for sweets, having recently learned I have symptoms of prediabetes. By accident I discovered that after eating extra dark chocolate I found my usual bland banana super sweet. After several days of trial, I found I could drink my usual chilled breakfast cocoa without adding milk. The net effect is that I could have a satisfying "dessert" that consists entirely of a teaspoon of skim milk and cinnamon, one-third cup oats diluted in water, and flavored by three tablespoons of cocoa powder!-

question_title: Downward Double-Vision
question_body: If I focus on the ring in this image (the ring is 1 cm tall on my monitor, I stand 300 cm away, the room is dark, and I cover one eye), I actually see an "8" formed from double-vision where the lower ring is dimmer.  So, I'd simply say that this lower ring is caused by a cataract. To be honest, the "cataract ring" is not just lower, but also slightly right; the off-vertical angle is roughly 20 degrees.  It's interesting that my other eye also has similar downward double-vision (with a smaller 10 degree rightward shift).  (I get even more cataract glare details when I focus on the small dot to the left, instead of the ring, but I'm trying to keep this question simple.) Do most people have downward double-vision in both eyes like me?  If so, is there any theory about why/how the eye changes asymmetrically as we age? I guess that the exact statistical study I'm suggesting here has never been done, but hope cataracts have been studied enough to answer theoretically.-

question_title: Should a partially detached toenail be trimmed away or left alone?
question_body: A few weeks ago I caught my toe (big toe, right foot) beneath a door when opening it.  The toenail took on a pink/purple color for a few days, and after spending some time in the ocean it became clear that the nail had mostly detached from the nail-bed underneath.   Specifically, there's about 3mm of healthy nail-bed still attached along the left edge of the toenail, and 4mm on the right edge.  The remaining central area of the nail is detached, straight from the tip all the way to the base of the nail (can slide a probe around in this space between the nail and the nail-bed easily and with no pain).  The detached area seems relatively normal, but is picking up a slight yellow tinge.   Would it normally be recommended to cut away the detached portion of the nail (leaving the healthy strips along each side intact), or to just leave it in place while it regrows?  What about in cases that involve frequent activities in lakes and/or oceans?-

question_title: Can my sleep issues/insomnia contribute to my new diet's effectivenes? [on hold]
question_body: I went through ALOT of life changes (divorce, moving, death in the family, new job) in the past year that attributed to poor dieting and weight gain. I was always a pretty chubby kid, but in my early 20s, I started taking better care of myself. I'm 5'3", 29yrs old. For the past 8/9 years Ive been a consistent 125lbs. In the past year, up until April I had gained 26lbs, 151lbs. During this stressful time I also started having issues with sleep, either days without any sleep, very little sleep, the inability to go back to sleep if I wake up at night, or hours of laying in bed with my eyes closed just aggravated that I was still awake. My doctor recommended I up my melatonin to 10mg per night, so I supplement with that nightly with little help. In April I started watching my diet because I felt so "blah", from my weight gain, heels sore, back sore, tight pants, let alone what it's done to my self esteem, I'm usually a pretty confident woman. I have cut ALL refined sugars, and bread, added a cup of beans to my diet daily, switched to skim milk instead of fattened milk or cream in my coffee, subbing coconut or olive oil instead of butter or margarine when cooking, fresh or frozen instead of canned veggies and fruit, salt substitute instead of salt, switched to lean meats only (turkey, chicken, fish) and have made breakfast my highest protein meal of the day. When I snack I snack on high fiber snacks, fruit or raw veggies, pretzels(one of my only packaged foods now, ugh), or part skim string cheese, and I drink water or coffee or homemade smoothies (I'm a sweet tea girl so this has been especially difficult). My activity has little change, I've just extended my dogs' walks to twice a day... I've lost 5lbs since April 16th, when I started. I would think with all the changes especially the higher fiber, cutting sugars, and switching from sweet tea to water, that I would've lost more in this much time. I stopped gaining which is good, but stepping on the scale and seeing 146lbs, was as far as I had reached was discouraging. Are my expectations too high? Or could my sleep issues be attributing to this?-

question_title: High liver values and different opinions from doctors
question_body: following story, note: this is a made up story of an individual  . No need to comment "oh sorry we cannot give advice" made up story, purely fictional there is a guy called bob, 31 years old. Bob likes binge drinking. He drinks until he is drunk each weekend. That is, friday and saturday. During for about 12 years. he does a liver blood exam, not because he feels sick, but for some other reason. his values are high, say like this: as well an ultra sound inspection is done, no fatty liver nor cirrhosis was detected.  the doctor says: if you keep doing this, you will die before reaching 35 years. When bob did the blood exam, the woman taking the blood samples told him "i have never seen someone with values that high, soon you will probably be in the hospital" so bob stops drinking. His blood levels normalize.  For example like to this levels: After a month or two he starts drinking again, same, only weekends. But binge drinking. After a month or two of drinking he does a test again. Blood values have risen again, not as high as before, but not in the normal spectrum. for example like this  So this game goes on, bob stops drinking for 6 months straight, liver values are great, then tries drinking again, same story, blood values rise. The doctor who diagnosed death before 35, lives and is from el salvador and is a nose ear throat doctor specialist. After two years and bob having basically given up on drinking, he goes to a liver expert in colombia. That doctor is supposed to be the best liver expert in a big city and leads a team of liver transplant surgeons. He studied in spain. The doctor is presented with all results. He orders another ultra sound examination. No fatty liver, no cirrhosis. His conclusion: your levels are nothing unusual. You are not sick at all. the exams of the blood tests are handed to another doctor in the same town. This doctor says "well they are a bit high yes, but nothing to worry about" what would you think? and yes yes "drinking is bad, no need to do it". So is driving a motorcycle.-

question_title: Questions on my upcoming ACL reconstruction surgery
question_body: I finally decided to have a surgery for my ACL since I tore it completely, and after taking so much time to think about it and gather opinions from doctors, friends, etc. I think is the best move I have right now.  On my last visit to the doctor, we talked briefly about how my surgery procedure will be, he told me that I have to make a decision on what kind of ligament do I want to get the ACL replacement from, the side part of my knee or the ligament under small bone of the knee, I'm sorry I just don't know the names of them.  I would like to ask what would be the best decision and why, I just don't know what would be the differences one over the other. The next question keeps me anxious. A friend that already got his ACL fixed told me that he got a shot in the back right before the surgery and that he was awake most of the time. I asked my doctor if that was going to be the case for me and he told me that he was going to put me a mask around my mouth and nose and he will put me to sleep for all the time of the surgery duration, I told this to my friend and he said I should be careful with that because if they leave the mask for more time than needed that I can get into a vegetative state which made me very nervous because I think that is worse than dying in my opinion, is this true? Also, I was wondering why some people get the anesthesia shot in their back and also make them breath something to make them go to sleep and to me he said he was going to put me to sleep with no shot, isn't the shot needed so I don't feel anything under my hips? Thank you for everyone that read my whole post!-

question_title: How can I make getting an IV easier?
question_body: I need an IV started once or twice a month, sometimes more often. This has been going on for a year now. It is getting harder and harder to get them started. 4 weeks ago it took three tries. Yesterday it took only one, but I was crying out in pain (it really burned) and ended up with tears streaming down my face. The nurse wanted to remove it but I didn't want to go through that twice so I had her keep going. Once the needle was in place, my vein spasmed shut. By concentrating on breathing and relaxing I managed to get the vein to open again. The blood draw they needed to do required a syringe to actually pull the blood out. However once the IV was hooked up and the meds were flowing in, I was fine for the next hour or so, and after it was removed. Things I know already: This rather small arsenal is not enough for me. I am very motivated to get these IVs started -- it's where the miracle goes in -- but the nurses really don't like pushing sharp metal into someone who is yelling ow and ouch, who is crying real tears, etc. And it's not the best part of my day. So, how can I make it go more smoothly?-

question_title: Why does sugar get such a bad rep?
question_body: Most reputable health organizations (if not all) recommend keeping your daily intake of sugar to as low as possible. At the same time, these same organizations acknowledge that carbohydrates are an essential macronutrient that the body needs to properly function and that about 50% of our caloric intake should come from them. Now, aren't these two recommendations completely contradictory? All carbohydrates that the body can absorb eventually get turned into glucose, a simple sugar like any other. Why is it bad to consume a bunch of table sugar (sucrose), for example, which is already half glucose and its other fructose half will also get converted into glucose anyway, but perfectly fine to consume other more complex carbohydrates that just like sucrose, will also end up being converted into glucose? If both, simple sugars and all other carbohydrates end up as glucose in the body, then why does one get a bad rep and not the other? What's the difference?-

question_title: Is a sinus rinse safe for Adderall insufflation
question_body: I structured my question into five paragraphs, So you can get more or less context. The last paragraph is the only one needed to answer the question. I am 17, male. I suffer from (I have been diagnosed several times, different mental health professionals) severe Bi-Polar/ADHD. Along with this is some degree of OCD, and  moderate Anxiety. My OCD/Anxiety changes in severity, sometimes I will get panic attacks just by thinking the wrong thing (bad thoughts) which I cope with via an involuntary shaking thing I do in addition to speaking involuntarily. Comparing to my ADHD, I always am distractible. I am also diagnosed with autism.  I cannot engage in dialog (even on my gaunfacine (brand name tenex) ), as my inability to concentrate causes me to be unable to listen to other people's responses that are longer than (4/5 to 3/2) of a sentence, by then i'm distracted. Looking back, I was basically trapped in my conscious. I would mumble often, and even say random things I was thinking about. I would be so distracted in my mind, I carried out daily activities like walking around, cooking, cleaning, all sub-consciously (until external stimuli comes, then I snap out of it and somehow am somewhat but not completely aware of whats been happening). This sub-concious action has resulted in me almost destroying a blender by screwing it the wrong direction. I was prescribed Adderall IR after asking my psychiatrist for a study aid. He gave me 20mg per day, and I take it discretionarily When I first started, 10mg IR oral allowed me to somewhat concentrate on the GED material I was studying for roughly 1-1.5 hours. At least concentrate long enough to pick up the material. 20mg IR oral was a miracle. On 20mg IR oral, I picked up mathematical concepts immediately. For GED, my first time taking 20mg IR, I understood conceptual how chords work, where before, when I took geometry in summer school, I only understood how to calculate them. In addition, I could finally understand people, social/human relationships. My grandmother was surprised at my ability to engage in dialog, and my ability to talk about topics others had interest in. I was even able to train myself to subconsciously pause for a few seconds after listening to someone in order to think about what they said before responding. This allowed me to understand people's perspectives very well. When taking an exam (GED or SAT) I needed to make sure meds last the whole time. If they begin wearing off, I needed to re-dose. Adderall takes 10-20 minutes to start kicking in orally for me and stop working after about 60-80 minutes orally, so this led me to research ways of getting it to kick it faster. I first found sub-lingual, which was on a mental health forum, funny enough it was for anxiety meds, but I google sub-lingual adderall and sure enough it works, so I tried 10mg IR sublingual and it felt like slightly over 20mg IR, kicking in after about a minute. I could study phenomenally, I was picking things up better than 20mg IR and after learning something I struggled with in highschool, I was overwhelmed with joy. I felt like I could reach my full potential. Over a few days I continued researching adderall, and while researching how effects differ when taking sub-lingual vs oral, there was a couple people talking about "snorting", at first I thought these people where just feins abusing adderall, until I ran into a post where a man who was prescribed it had used nasal insufflation late in the night to get some desk work done. He said 5mg IR insufflated is very powerful, but lasted long enough to do work he had. I decided to try this method, I crushed up a 5mg, and crushed it up with a morter-pestal. I then placed it on my desk and made it a pile. I pinched about 1.5mg-2mg worth and put it on my fingertip. I then held the finger to one nostril, covered the other, and inhaled hard. It started with this addrenaline rush which lasted maybe a half minute, and for the next 5-10 minutes I had superb concentration on the english material I was studying. This method is perfect to me because if one portion of an english assignment is more challenging for me to concentrate on, I administer more, then in a few minutes I move to study a new concept. If that concept is easy for me to concentrate on, I administer less. I worry about neurotoxicity, and if I can get by on a lower dose that means less potential for brain damage. I read that nasal insufflation, done this way can be harmful to the nasal cavities. This gave me the Idea of sinus rinse bottles.  They (sinus rinse bottles) are designed to clear sinuses by pouring water in one nostril, and it flows through the sinus clearing through the other nostril. If I dissolve a dose of Adderall in a small amount of water, it goes through and absorbs through mucus. I plug my other nostril to maximize Adderall absorption. Then pour the water into a bowl. Is this method safer to direct contact?-

question_title: Optimal amount and type of physical excersise [closed]
question_body: At university I was actually a decent runner, because I lived in dormitory near the stadium and joined our faculty track and field team (never won any contests, but anyway). Now I'm working as a programmer, sitting too much at my desk and already notice that sometimes I have a muffin top. This another thing I want to fix, but I'm guess that it is best fixed with reducing amount of consumed sugar and carbohydrates, and not so critical, because it is not visible under my shirt. So I regard this as just a signal that something needs to change. What I'm actually want to fix is the constant fatigue I had because of working at startup, constantly overtiming, missing deadlines, dealing with changing requirements and other development stress. You probably know how it could be. I'm going to try to find more balanced job, but I guess I need to change my lifestyle too.  So, how much exercise is optimal to have the most energy? And what kind of exercise should it be? Should I run for 20 minutes every morning, or should I do it only 3-4 times a week? 3 times a week means I could save time and have less clothes to wash and shoes have time to dry, but every day will be better to build a habit. Optimizing for endorphins is another priority, because I actually want to create habit. In university it was because socializing (I rarely went to the stadium alone, now I'm exercising alone.) Should I try to find friends in some fitness club? Or would some push-ups or squats in pomodoro breaks be enought? Any other suggestions for healthy pomodoro break fillers? Or "No pain, no gain" is true, and I just need to try to push myself to the limit every day? I once went to some fitness and nutrition seminar made by trainers of some gym. They talked a lot about how to lift more weight, but when I asked what to do if I want to be better in sport like chess, they laughed at me, like chess is not sport.   But I'm not trying to become elite athlete, I want to become better and more happy and efficient programmer.-

question_title: Why does prosopagnosia (face blindness) only affect recognition of faces?

The precise causes, as I understand it, are not well-known, although it is believed to be related to damage in the right fusiform gyrus: As far as I'm aware, the fusiform gyrus has functions beyond facial recognition and analysis - although my knowledge of how facial recognition in the brain works is limited. Therefore, my nave logic is that damage to the region should also damage other (related) mental abilities, yet I can't find much information about other disabilities prosopagnosiacs may face, if any. If prosopagnosia does arise from damage to the fusiform gynus, why are the effects merely limited to facial perception? If the effects are not this limited, are there any minor disabilities associated with the condition?-w47f

question_title: Minor feral cat scratch that bled 6 days ago. Rabies possibility?
question_body: I feed a feral cat and her litter of 4 5-week old kittens in my backyard. I got a small scratch on my hand which bled for a few minutes and heard it hiss. That's when the mom came and proceeded to lick it. After freaking out for a bit, I decided to go the ER and was given the first dosage of post exposure shots (2 on each arm, and 1 at the site of the scratch).   I didn't go to the ER three days later as I was supposed to. I don't have a way to quarantine all the cats but they do house themselves in a shed. Every so often, I check on them and I don't see any neurological differences, salivation, or any other telltale symptoms like disorientation or aggression. On any of the cats, I don't see any injuries. I'll still continue to observe each of them, especially the one that scratched me which allows me to pet it, as I still have a 1% doubt since it hasn't been 10-14 days since I started observation.  I would continue the vaccinations but money is a concern as well. Also, I looked up a report of rabies cases in my county (Hudson of NJ), and I was very surprised to see that there have only been 5 cases of rabid cats from 1989 to 2016 and only 18 raccoons in the same time frame. It's the only county in NJ to have a total of double digit cases among all reported animals while the other counties were in the several hundreds.  What is the risk vs benefit of getting the next rabies shot?-

question_title: how does the immune system identify allergens? application: varenicline and lobeline
question_body: I'm wondering if we know how the immune system identifies allergens. My biochemistry knowledge is basic so I apologize if I use concepts incorrectly! Specifically, I want to know about the likelihood of having an allergic reaction to something, given an allergy to something else...  I'll clarify the situation with the following example:  Say a person develops an allergy to some molecule, A. Another molecule, B, has a different skeletal structure. A and B are both thought to have a similar mechanisms for the treatment of some medical problem. If a person is allergic to A, are they more likely to be allergic to B? To make this even more concrete, let's say a person is allergic to varenicline, a synthetic molecule used to treat nicotine addiction. Is that person more likely to be allergic to Lobeline (indian tobacco)? They have different skeletal formulas, but varenicline is an agonist on nicotine acetlycholine receptors, while lobeline is a mixed agonist-antagonist on these receptors. (Maybe this is not relevant?).  Does the fact that both molecules have similar neurochemical mechanisms of action on dopamine receptors, have any implications as to whether the immune system would identify the new molecule as an allergen? What about an allergen, physical or chemical, is it that the immune system is actually ID'ing or remembering? Disclaimer: I have an allergy to varenicline, and considered taking lobeline until i read they have similar neurochemical mechanisms. I'm not looking for advice, because I am not going to take lobeline. I'm just curious. Thanks in advance for any insight!-

question_title: Is added sugar itself an issue, or what goes along with it?
question_body: I'm not really fond of that title, but there is only so much space. Pretty much, from reading online, which seems to be among the least reliable sources for dietary information, the issue with added sugar is a combination of lower nutrient to calorie ratio, "damage" to gut bacteria, and increasing glycemic index. That is to say that everyday you need a certain amount of nutrients and calories. You don't want to exceed the calorie limit, and you don't want a nutrient deficient so a low nutrient:calorie food can cause issues. Then, foods with a high glycemic index cause spikes in blood sugar which cause all sorts of damage even before you take into consideration the insulin spike that follows. As for the effect on gut bacteria, the more pathogenic strains tend to also be the ones that like sugar and fat. Or so I've been led to believe. I have the least information on this. From my understanding, these are the reasons added sugar is a problem. It seems to me that if I can mitigate these three issues, then adding a bit of sugar (not talking about cups of the stuff) to my baking shouldn't be an issue. For context, I'm not talking about buying pre-made foods, or processed foods. I do not eat those. Rather I am thinking exclusively about my baking. In particular, or as an example if you will, my "bran" muffins. They aren't really bran muffins since the original bran recipe i developed was cost prohibitive (gluten-free oat bran costs a fortune! Gluten-free is a must due to Celiacs.), but rather flax meal and chia seed muffins that use whole oat flour, quinoa flour, almond flour, and cinnamon. Yes, cinnamon is a major ingredient...as in 1/3 of a cup (probably a dangerous amount). I'm looking to address the issue of added sugar before going forward with an expensive sequence of experimentation to develop a new muffin recipe as well as well as keep in consideration for future recipes that I may make.-

question_title: Paramyotonia congenita - Total-body cramp, weakness in all muscles, difficult to swallow / lift leg in sitting position
question_body: The subject symptoms happen to me from time to time. I'm told it's related to a rare muscular disorder that I suffer from... I believe the name is  . What's really strange though, is that this condition generally only affects me in cold weather... eyes freezing shut, face looking like I've had a stroke, hands useless for writing or typing purposes (or really purpose at all, in fact). The cold-weather stuff is manageable. It's something that I can physically avoid, by staying inside during the cold months. Or by wearing super warm gloves, face and eye warmers, etc. But the issue I'm posting about here is unrelated to that. Or seemingly unrelated. From time to time, for no apparent reason, I find myself with one of these total-body cramps. A light cramp... sort of a cross between total weakness/paralysis and a slight crawling feeling throughout my body. Much stronger mostly in my frontal neck, facial area, abdomen, and quadriceps. But felt elsewhere as well. It's a lot more terrible than it may sound, and generally lasts for 1-2hrs at a time and appears out of nowhere. My research has shown that the symptoms are very similar to a low blood sugar or diabetic episode. Last time this happened (about two weeks ago), I actually got one of those blood sugar testers and happened to have not eaten yet that day, so the test was legit and showed it was exactly where it was supposed to be. And this was in the middle of one of these weird muscular episodes, so blood sugar is removed as a culprit. Is this something that anyone else out there is experiencing? Have you treated someone with similar symptoms? I know it's a rare disorder so not expecting much, I suppose. Any recommendations (outside of "see a doc") would be most appreciated!-

question_title: Can I use take pills to prevent micronutrient deficiencies and not worry about my diet too much?
question_body: There are several nutrients which I'm not getting enough of from food, in some cases hardly any, due to dietary restrictions. I   get the nutrients I need if I carefully structure my diet, but I don't want to. I'm really lazy. I'm still trying to eat a varied diet including plenty of fruits and veggies, I just know it's not enough. So I'm taking a multivitamin and a couple of other pills. Pretty much all the information I can find suggests this is a bad idea, but none of it seems to directly answer why. The biggest apparent reason is that supplements are not absorbed as well as food. But I can't see any indication of how well supplements are absorbed. I know it depends on a lot of factors (including the dosage) and is probably hard to measure, but don't we have at least a rough idea in specific situations? If I take, say, 100% of the RDA of iron in a pill, is the amount my body absorbs probably more or less than 50%? How much do caffeine, vitamin C, calcium, etc. affect the absorption? The information always seems to be qualitative, not quantitative. Furthermore, if a certain dosage won't be sufficiently absorbed to fulfill my requirements, why can't I just take more? I know that this leads to diminishing returns and high dosages can be problematic, but that doesn't quite explain it. The amounts found in supplements are generally on the order of 100% of the RDA,   less than the amounts which are considered risky which are more like 1000% (with the exception of calcium, where there are some concerns about supplementing around 100-200%). It's hard to believe that the cost of manufacturing the pills or the difficulty of swallowing them would significantly increase in many cases, especially when we're talking about adding a few milligrams or less. Other than that, many of the fears seem irrelevant. Don't take certain dangerous supplements like the dirty dozen. Don't make certain combinations. Don't try to use supplements to treat diseases like cancer. And so on. Is the problem uncertainty? Does it just seem safer to tell people to get their vitamins from food? Or perhaps do some people know what can and should be done but others are still catching up? OK, that's a lot of rambling, let me try and make a coherent, SE style question: Suppose I'm a healthy adult between the ages of 20 and 40. I don't know of any medical conditions that I have relevant to supplements. I am not currently deficient in anything. I can afford to buy as many supplements as I need, I remember to take them, and I don't mind doing so. EDIT: it looks like I need to clarify. I'm vegan. There are several nutrients that I can't easily get from food, particularly B12, calcium, and vitamin D. My diet is generally fairly good - plenty of fruits, veggies, nuts, and grains - but that doesn't help enough with those nutrients. Yes some vegetables have calcium but I don't want to eat, say, 600g of kale every day. It seems safe to say that I need calcium in my body, so I want to know if pills work for that. I'm not suggesting living on junk food and pills.-

question_title: Why is acid reflux (allegedly) often confused with chest pain?

Supposedly, heart and circulatory related pain is neither sharp nor short, so this pain may be muscle or lung-lining related. (I also haven't had any shortness of breath, nausea, or fatigue).  I've had plenty of acid reflux over the years (stomach acid gets into my throat and burns like crazy until addressed), and I just don't understand why, whenever I try to look for information about my mystery chest pain, I'm forced to hear about something as seemingly irrelevant as acid reflux. It's like calling tech support and they ask you if your computer's plugged in. Am I missing something here? Can acid reflux cause actual chest pain, and not just esophageal pain? If it can, then how? I'm under the impression that the digestive system is a closed system, and that a stomachache shouldn't cause, say, shoulder pain or a backache. (edit: I found somewhat similar question, and it's answers mention esophageal spasms, but are such symptoms common enough to be relevant, and would they actually cause chest pain? would it not be obvious that the source of the pain is the esophagus?)-

question_title: Should medical accessories for drug administration that come in contact with mucous membranes need to be washed and cleaned before first use?
question_body: Certain medical accessories for drug administration, such as syringes   for babies, applicators for vaginal ovules, inhalers and so on, come in direct contact with mucous membranes (e.g. mouth, vagina).  These accessories are usually made from plastic and are (most probably) sterilized before being packed, so getting an infection from using them is unlikely. However, they are produced from different raw materials (again, mostly plastic) and I do not know whether these industrial processes leave some kind of residue on the accessory, and whether this residue can be harmful to the body when inserted directly into the body. Consumer leaflets do not address the issue of first use and whether these instruments should be cleaned before used for the first time. So, -

question_title: Cold weather has caused a red rash around my eyes
question_body: I'm originally from Sydney (a warm city) and I had been living in Seattle (a city that experiences snow sometimes). During the cold weather, I'd sometimes get tears in my eyes. I was starting to get a red rash around one eye and the skin would be dry, so I would apply moisturiser, but it didn't really seem to improve, so I also started using petroleum jelly (advertised as being useful for dry lips). I returned to Australia for a few weeks and it cleared up. In February, I moved to New York and was fine for at least a month, but the cold weather again brought on the tears and the dry, red skin worse than before, around both eyes. I would sometimes dry my eyes on the inner joint of my elbows and I now have rashes there too. The weather in New York is now fine; sometimes even too hot. It's been a month or two since my eyes have watered in the cold, but I still have the red, dry skin around my eyes. I thought it might be a fungal infection, so I applied some anti-fungal medicine rather than moisturiser one night, just around the eyes, being very careful to avoid the eyelids. Awakening the next morning, my skin was totally dried out I had large, cracked segments of skin. This quickly flaked off and I'm back to dry, rough red skin around my eyes, on the scale of racoon's eyes. I've been applying the anti-fungal cream to my elbow joints for a week or two now with no effect except perhaps for a reduced itchiness after application. Can anyone please advise what's going on? My pharmacist advised just to keep my skin moisturised around the eyes and said that the petroleum jelly would indeed be a reasonable approach. I had a blood test in Seattle and had no sexual diseases then btw. In the past 2 or 3 weeks, I've also developed rashes on my neck that look like ringworm  this was the main reason for the anti-fungal medicine. Idk if that's related.-vo312k

question_title: Why do I cry when I vomit? [on hold]
question_body: I have noticed that my body has a specific response when I vomit and that what part of the response is going on depends on the timing. Here is that response from feeling nauseous to after vomiting: I start groaning because I am nauseous. Around that same time I start burping excessively as my stomach is upset. This causes me to get reflux into the esophagus and eventually into the mouth. But reflux does not equal vomiting. There are still more things that happen. When the reflux starts getting really bad, I get up and go to the bathroom and depending on severity, I might be covering my mouth or just walking slowly. If I am covering my mouth, I vomit and that is that, no further response. If I am just walking slowly though, there is still more to happen. After I slowly walk to the bathroom, I put my index finger into the back of my mouth to trigger vomiting. I start gagging because that is a reflex and initially my salivary glands are inhibited but afterwards they are stimulated more than usual so I secrete more saliva. This is also around the time that my eyes start watering. This could be going on for minutes with nothing besides reflux. I start actively contracting my abdominal muscles in waves to help the stomach push gastric juices up and out. Finally gastric juices come out and depending on if and when I drank water, it could all end up in the toilet or be more explosive(dilute gastric juices tends to equal more explosive vomiting). Sometimes it is just gastric juices that come out and sometimes partially digested food comes out too. If I have been vomiting a lot because of a stomach virus, green bile comes out along with the yellow gastric juices and the partly digested food, especially in the evening.  During all this time, my eyes water a lot. But why do my eyes water when I vomit? Does it have to do with the vagus nerve stimulation that causes the vomiting? -

question_title: Glutamate substitute for ALS?
question_body: I was just reading up on some ALS literature, and noted something on a newly diagnosed patient. The (current) assessment is that this particular patient's ALS symptoms are caused by a glutamate deficiency. What is interesting is that the patient is a Type 2 diabetic, which would hint at that as an original source for the deficiency, as glutamate is typically synthesized in cells from glucose. But glutamate can also be synthesized, in cells, from aspartate, as in aspartame. The patient claims to have stopped drinking sugar-free beverages about a year ago, for personal reasons, which roughly lines up with the onset of the symptoms. Could it be that the patient has been unknowingly substituting glucose-to-glutamate synthesis with aspartate-to-glutamate synthesis and the change in diet stopped that? And is it maybe possible to add aspartame products to the diet and get that work-around running again, to reduce glutamate deficiency symptoms? I sadly lack access to ALS experts around here, so I thought this could be a place to ask.-

question_title: Pain in foot and knee after running [on hold]
question_body: Since a few days I have been having some problems with my right foot, as I cannot walk on it. There's some backstory to it, but i'll keep it as short as possible Three weeks ago i started running every evening to get some exercise. I'm starting of really slow to get used to running. In my day to day shoes i have tailored support insoles (hope this is clear, i am not sure if this is the proper translation) because i have flat feet. I've been walking on these kinds of insoles for a couple of years. The problems started when i got blisters on my foot on the places where the insoles where correcting my flat feet. I also thought is was a good idea to buy an extra pair of shoes for running so i bought a new pair of running shoes without the insoles, so i wouldn't get blisters. This worked for a couple of days but yesterday i started having some minor pain in my right foot and knee while running and when i woke op this morning and stepped out of my bed i just fell over immediately as i collapsed through my foot. Every step hurts and if i make one wrong step i almost fall over. Of course i am not running this evening, but what are the next steps? should i see a doctor or should i just wait to see what happens? and more importantly, what should i do with running? should i keep doing what i am doing or should i buy new insoles (which are really expensive) in my running shoes and just accept the blisters? or should i stop completely with running and find other exercise? Thanks in advance for any help Regards, Harm-

I also read about Post Partum Insomnia which is normal for new moms. I read all over the internet about the horror of having Insomnia and I feel bad that I can't do anything for her.  According to what I also read breastfeeding can cause Estrogen hormones decrease thus it will result to Insomnia. Yes, we tried to seek help from health professionals but they just gave us Iterax to help my wife fall asleep, but it just produce the same result where my wife can sleep 4 hours only. We already tried herbal medicines too but it doesn't work.  The only solution that we made is that we weaned our little girl after 1 month and 3 weeks, and she can sleep now better. Though I don't agree weaning our child in the first place, because I know how precious breastmilk is for babies, but I can't even let my wife fall apart. So the question: Is the insomnia experienced by my wife is due to its PCOS or having low hormones in the first place? P.S. I didn't place the link of the articles where I read the information but you can just use the keywords "post partum insomnia","PCOS", "breastfeeding" in google to get my references.-

question_title: Are there any insulin pumps which are attached for more than a few days?
question_body: People with Type II Diabetes requiring long-acting insulin can inject themselves once a day with a syringe or insulin pen, but there is an alternative to that: insulin pumps.  Insulin pumps provide a continuous supply of rapid-acting insulin throughout the day, which has the same effect on the body as one daily injection of long-acting insulin.  (And if you require mealtime insulin, you can get the insulin pump to deliver a "bolus" or extra amount of insulin.) Now insulin pumps come in two types: tube pumps and patch pumps.  Tube pumps require you to inject a new injection set into your skin every 2-3 days.  Concerning patch pumps, there are two patch pumps on the market, V-Go which is injected once every 24 hours, and Omnipod which is injected once every 3 days.  There are also insulin ports like the I-Port, which is also injected once every three days. But my question is, are there any insulin pumps (or ports) which you can keep attached to your skin for more than a few days?  I just want to minimize the frequency of injections as much as possible.  Something that you just inject once and then it stays attached for two weeks or a month would be great.-

question_title: Are there any non-injection methods of delivering long-acting insulin?
question_body: is an inhaler that delivers rapid-acting insulin through inhaling rather than injection.  But my question is, are there any methods of delivering long-acting insulin that do not require an injection? Insulin syringes (like the ones used with Toujeo and Triceba), insulin pumps (like Medtronic), patch pumps (like V-Go), insulin ports (like I-Port), and insulin jet injectors (like Insujet) all require an injection of some kind.  But does anyone know a way to deliver long-acting insulin, either inhalable like Affreza or some other method that doesn't involve injection in any way? Note that this is about Type II diabetes, not Type I.-

question_title: Stomach pain after drinking alcohol

The strange part is that this resolves within 10 to 15 minutes usually after which no adverse effects remain other then the usual intoxication to be expected in proportion to the alcohol intake. The pain usually starts almost immediately after consuming a drink (with a lagging period of about two minutes top) and reaches its apex around 5 minutes after ingestion. Then it remains consistent for roughly 10 minutes after which it subsides within minutes. The pain is serious enough that I have to go lie down (7/10 easily, would be higher if it would persist over longer periods). I have had this with a wide variety of beverages; Beer, wine, liquors and mix drinks all alike. When it happens seems to be completely random, doesn't matter whether I've eaten or not. Does anyone know what could possibly be causing this? Assumption: My stomach is completely healthy, no stomach ulcurs, gastritis or other forms of stomach ailments what so ever. My liver is also completely healthy. I do have irritable bowel syndrome in case that's relevant. -

question_title: Is it possible for a healthy person to drown in their sleep without waking up?
question_body: In reading about the horrific Battle of Passchendaele during World War One, I came across an anecdotal account of a British officer sheltering in a shell hole in a rain storm. The narrator claims that this officer had no wounds, and had fallen asleep on the wall of the crater while the muddy water it contained was only a foot deep.  The next morning, when the narrator awoke, the officer was still not physically wounded, but the muddy liquid had risen considerably overnight, covering the officer's face and drowning him in his sleep. I have a hard time believing that an uninjured, healthy person with no neurological or physiological problems would be able to sleep through something like this.  I'm sure many of you have experienced the acute physical discomfort and emotionally jarring panic of unintentionally inhaling water - failing to notice the sensations would be virtually  impossible.  If healthy people could sleep through drowning, the form of torture known as "waterboarding" would presumably be unremarkable rather than horrific. And I know from experience that if you cover your big brother's mouth and nose while he's asleep, he wakes up very quickly (and punches you repeatedly).-

question_title: What is the minimum energy needed to stay alive?
question_body: This is a bit of an odd question, but here goes. Your body needs energy to function. Each organ (brain, heart, etc.) need different amounts of energy to function properly. So it stands to reason that your heart's minimum required energy is higher than that of your spleen (just an example). So here's my question: "Which organ requires the most minimum energy, and how much energy is the minimum?" I'm asking this question because I'm trying to figure out "if energy were removed from a body, such that all parts of the body had the exact same amount of energy, what would be the minimum energy needed to make sure no organs failed" (this has to do with World Building, to an extent). Furthermore, it'd be very helpful to know how much energy would be required for said organ not only for survival, but also to maintain a relatively normal, or even active, functionality. Would this equal the energy normally found in a person, or could it be lower? If I need to clarify further, just let me know. Thank you in advance!-

question_title: Not losing visceral fat (beer belly)
question_body: About two months ago I decided that I want live a more active lifestyle and get back to the weight and fitness level I used to be at. I can feel myself getting fitter but just not losing the beer belly. I have read that visceral fat is harder to get rid of than subcutaneous fat but I would have expected to lose at least a little bit. Before I started exercising my waist was 103.5 and now its roughly still the same at 105.3 cm. This is my belly today: I eat a bowl of cereal (no sugar) for breakfast and mainly red meat with veges for dinner so I am almost certain that my calorie intake isn't over the top. I don't snack during the day either. I used to drink quite a lot of alcohol so I guess this is where I got my beer belly from, I stopped drinking and replaced that with coke and since roughly two months ago I only drink Coke Zero which has no calories. I drink about 2 liters a day to fix my sugar craving from the real coke. I know I should be drinking more water and the next step is to quit coke zero and go onto water.
